summary: What's News: Business & Finance Top Stories for Oct. 18, 2011

summary: Corrections & Amplifications for Oct. 17, 2011.

headline: Deals India: Morning News Roundup
summary: News roundup from Indian newspapers, news wires and Web sites on Wednesday, October 19, 2011. Deals India has not verified the stories from other media organizations and does not vouch for their accuracy.

headline: What's the Dirtiest College-Football Rivalry?
summary: An analysis of the roughest rivalries, based on late hits and unsportsmanlike-conduct penalties.

headline: Asia in Pictures
summary: South Korean soldiers perform during a welcoming ceremony, exiled Tibetan monks in India pray for their people, a woman cries as her dead son's body was taken by mistake in Indonesia, and more.

headline: Car Bomb in Somali Capital Kills 4
summary: A suicide car bomb exploded near Somalia's Foreign Ministry, killing at least four people, including the bomber, as government leaders met in the capital with Kenya's ministers of defense and foreign affairs.

headline: DOJ to Hire Litigator for AT&T Case
summary: The Justice Department is planning to hire Glenn Pomerantz, a partner at Munger Tolles & Olson, to help in its antitrust case against AT&T's proposed $39 billion bid for T-Mobile USA.

headline: Foreign Investors Boost U.S. Treasury Holdings
summary: Major foreign investors bought up U.S. Treasurys in August amid Europe's growing debt crisis, with the exception of top foreign holder China.

headline: Coke Net Up; Costs Mount
summary: Coca-Cola's third-quarter earnings rose 8.1% as the company sold more drinks in each region. But the beverage giant projects commodity costs rising $800 million this year, up about $100 million from its prior estimate.

headline: Jenkins: Wi-Fi and the Mobile Meltdown
summary: Hotspots may be the workaround for the spectrum 'shortage.'

headline: Notable & Quotable
summary: Donald Boudreaux on Rep. Barbara Lee's refusal to use computer checkout lines at supermarkets because "that's a job or two or three that's gone."

headline: JetBlue's CFO Resigns
summary: JetBlue said CFO Ed Barnes has resigned. The company didn't say why.

headline: Second IPO Since Drought Prices Below Range
summary: Zeltiq Aesthetics, which makes a medical device that is marketed as a noninvasive way to eliminate "love handles," priced its initial public offering at $13 a share on Tuesday, below its expected range of $14 to $16.

headline: CSX's Profit Rises 12%
summary: CSX reported a 12% rise in third-quarter profit as price increases outweighed the railroad's anemic volume growth amid the soft economy.

headline: Fannie, Freddie Told to Change Foreclosure Lawyer System
summary: A U.S. housing regulator, responding to last year's "robo-signing" scandal, has ordered mortgage-finance titans Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to revamp the system for hiring law firms to process foreclosure cases.

headline: Crude Ends Higher
summary: U.S. oil futures advanced to their highest finish in a month, moving in lockstep with the rallying stock market and shrugging off concerns about weakening Chinese economic growth.

headline: Canada Bill Details Plans for Wheat Board
summary: The Conservative government made good on its promise to introduce legislation to dismantle the Canadian Wheat Board. The bill submitted Tuesday would put in a management team to restructure and sell off parts of the agency within five years.

headline: Euro Rebounds Vs. Dollar
summary: The euro rose modestly against the dollar in late trade following a report that France and Germany had agreed to increase the size of Europe's financial rescue fund.

headline: Oracle to Buy Endeca Technologies
summary: Oracle plans to acquire closely held Endeca Technologies for an undisclosed amount, bolstering its portfolio of products that help businesses analyze information.

headline: Judge Says Grupo Mexico Owes $1.3 Billion on Copper Deal
summary: A Delaware judge said Grupo Mexico owes more than $1.3 billion to minority shareholders of its Southern Peru Copper unit in a case stemming from a restructuring that contributed to the bankruptcy of Asarco.

headline: Palladium Prices Likely to Rise
summary: Russia's plans to stop selling palladium from its stockpile have rekindled talk of higher prices for the metal, which is widely used in car-exhaust filters and electronics. Russia's sales have kept world palladium supplies in surplus.

headline: Markdowns Put Goldman in the Red
summary: Goldman swung to a third-quarter loss, hit by markdowns on equity investments and declines in revenue from underwriting and fixed-income trading.

headline: How to Win a Free Fight to Japan...Maybe
summary: The Wall Street Journal's Japan Real Time (wsj.com/japanrealtime) this week looked at how to nab one of the proposed free flights to Japan, the hike in number of jet scrambles related to China and how Yoshihiko Noda is the country's poorest prime minister.

headline: Pennsylvania Advances Harrisburg Plan
summary: Pennsylvania moved a step closer to taking over the recovery plan of financially troubled Harrisburg, as the state Senate passed a bill Tuesday giving the governor the authority to declare a fiscal emergency in the state capital.

headline: Debt Echo
summary: Boiling down Moody's verbiage, it essentially has a negative outlook on France's stable outlook, an unusually convoluted stance. As usual, the market is far ahead of both the politicians and the companies. As euphoria around the planned plan has faded, so has French debt. Its 10-year bonds now yield more than one percentage point above its safer neighbor, Germany.

headline: Apotex Payment in Plavix Case Reduced
summary: A court has reduced by over $100 million the payment Apotex must make to Sanofi and Bristol-Myers Squibb for having sold generic copies of the popular blood thinner Plavix in violation of a patent in 2006.

headline: Harley Weighed Down by Margin Worries
summary: Harley-Davidson's road to more efficient manufacturing is proving bumpier than expected.

headline: Copper Trims Losses
summary: Copper futures regained some ground as equity markets reversed course in afternoon trade, but the metal's price still settled 0.5% lower.

headline: Gold Futures Settle Lower
summary: Gold trimmed its losses while silver pushed into positive territory as a weakening dollar and gains in risky assets eased the pressure on precious metals.

headline: State Street Profit Edges Up
summary: State Street reported a 1.6% increase in third-quarter profit as well as an interest in making acquisitions in Europe and buying back more of its stock.

headline: Starbucks to Offer Light-Roast Coffees
summary: Starbucks on Tuesday said it will introduce new light roast coffees to attract customers who don't like darker roasts.

headline: China's Need for Speed
summary: China's economy continues to purr along. But expect a clanking of gears as Beijing shifts policy to support growth.

headline: Viacom Seeks To Revive Lawsuit Against YouTube
summary: A judge's order dismissing an infringement lawsuit against YouTube last year should be overturned because it endangers the rights of owners of copyrighted materials, Viacom argues.

headline: Gilad Shalit is Set Free
summary: The Hamas militant group released Israeli soldier Gilad Shalit more than five years after his capture, turning him over to Egyptian mediators in exchange for hundreds of Palestinian prisoners.

headline: How Credit Adjustments Are Juicing Banks' Earnings
summary: Investors in bank stocks should take the latest round of quarterly earnings with a pinch of salt, given the effects some contentious accounting metrics have had on their income statements, according to market observers.

headline: Domino's Net Jumps 33%
summary: Domino's Pizza profit grew 33% in the latest quarter, helped by its new pizza recipe and other menu innovations, as well as international expansion.

headline: Treasury Prices Push Higher
summary: Global economic concerns trumped a jump in U.S. producer prices to nudge Treasury prices higher through the session.

headline: Germany Fines Coffee Makers
summary: Kraft Foods, Krüger cited for fixing prices of instant cappuccino.

headline: UnitedHealth Raises Outlook but Expresses Caution
summary: UnitedHealth again reported better-than-expected earnings and raised its outlook as it continued to benefit from muted health-care usage, but the health insurer said conditions could get tougher.

headline: 'Momentary' NYSE Hiccup Hits Caterpillar, 33 Other Stocks
summary: The New York Stock Exchange said it experienced a "momentary" interruption Tuesday that affected trading in nearly three dozen stocks, including Dow Jones Industrial Average component Caterpillar Inc. and a handful of airline stocks.

headline: New Zealand Ship Spills More Oil
summary: A stranded cargo vessel off New Zealand has spilled more oil into the ocean, as efforts to pump the remaining oil off the ship are hampered by bad weather.

headline: Indonesian Ministers Named
summary: Indonesian President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono named the remaining members of his new cabinet on Tuesday; his choices are unlikely to rock the boat, analysts said, and may not be able to push through needed economic changes.

headline: Asia Lifts Danone Sales
summary: French dairy giant Danone released encouraging sales data for the third quarter following a surge in demand in Asia and other non-European markets.

headline: Aiyar: Indian Bureaucrats Are No Steve Jobs
summary: The subsidized dirt-cheap tablet is the latest in a line of dangerous government gambles.

headline: China's Economic Growth Slows
summary: China's economic growth slowed in the third quarter but remained at a relatively healthy pace, adding to evidence that the Chinese economy is headed for a soft landing.

headline: India's Right Decision on Palestine
summary: India's support for Palestine is not a "foreign policy mishap."

headline: Malaysia's Economic Program Is a Success
summary: Malaysia's Economic Transformation Program is on track to create more than 370,000 new jobs.

headline: There is R&D in China,But Not by the Chinese
summary: China is far behind the developed world in R&D, and little progress is being made.

headline: New World Development Plans Capital-Raising
summary: New World Development proposes to raise as much as US$1.59 billion from a rights issue in Hong Kong, in a move aimed at strengthening its capital base.

headline: High-Frequency Trading's New Frontier: Currency Derivatives
summary: Banks and a growing number of hedge funds are handing over management of their currency options risks to computers, a possible sign that banks are finding it difficult to make money exchanging currency for clients.

headline: Japan to Kick-Start Key Policy Council
summary: Japan's government hopes to hold this month an inaugural meeting of a new national strategy council to compile a badly needed growth strategy.

headline: Assured Guaranty Restates Earnings for Accounting Errors
summary: Bond insurer Assured Guaranty said it will restate its financial results going back to the middle of 2009 after discovering an error related to its accounting for so-called variable-interest entities

headline: Ugandan Police to Charge Protestors With Treason
summary: Ugandan police accused opponents of President Yoweri Museveni of a plot to overthrow the government and said 15 people arrested in antigovernment protests this week would be charged with treason.

headline: Dexia Belgium Set for Nationalization
summary: Troubled Franco-Belgian bank Dexia said it expects to conclude plans for the Belgian state to take control of its Dexia Bank Belgium unit at a board meeting scheduled for Wednesday.

headline: Sinohydro Shares Halted on Debut
summary: State-owned Sinohydro Group made a surprisingly strong debut in Shanghai on Tuesday because of speculative buying early in the session, but its shares ended well below their intraday peak because of broader market weakness.

headline: EMC Posts Strong Results
summary: EMC posted robust quarterly results and said demand for its products remains strong, alleviating worries about a slowdown in technology spending.

headline: Iowa GOP Sets Jan. 3 Caucus Date
summary: Iowa Republicans will hold their traditional first-in-the-nation caucuses on Jan. 3 after state party officials approved the date Monday night in a move that lends more clarity to the GOP nominating process.

headline: India Appoints Two More Directors to RBI Board
summary: India's federal government has appointed two more directors to the central board of the Reserve Bank of India.

headline: Europe Doubts Dent Asia Markets
summary: Asian stocks ended sharply lower as Germany tempered expectations that euro-zone debt crisis can be completely resolved this week and Chinese data spurred slowdown concerns; Hong Kong's Hang Seng led the way with a 4.2% dive.

headline: Turkish Media Group Sells TV Station
summary: Turkey's largest media company said it has sold one of its three television stations for $327 million, in a move that appeared to draw a line under a long struggle for influence with the government.

headline: Hero MotoCorp Profit Rises 19%
summary: Hero MotoCorp beat market expectations with a 19% jump in second-quarter net profit, as record vehicle sales helped outweigh higher depreciation and raw-material costs.

headline: Omnicom Profit Grows
summary: Ad-agency holding company Omnicom Group posted a 17% rise in third-quarter earnings, propelled by international sales.

headline: European Sovereign Credit Ratings
summary: A look at the long-term, foreign currency credit ratings assigned to European sovereign borrowers by the three major ratings agencies; sort by country or agency.

headline: EU Warns Portugal on Deficit
summary: Portugal may not meet its targets for reducing its budget deficit in 2011 as required for the country to receive bailout funds, EU Economic and Monetary Affairs Commissioner Olli Rehn said.

headline: TCS to Cut Costs to Protect Margin
summary: Tata Consultancy Services will cut costs and focus on high-margin services to maintain its profitability in the traditionally weak October-December quarter, the software exporter's chief financial officer said.

headline: Maruti Suzuki Loses $307 Million Revenue on Strike
summary: Maruti Suzuki India has incurred a revenue loss of 15 billion rupees ($306.7 million) since Aug. 29 as labor woes at one of its factories have severely impacted vehicle output.

headline: Santander Slams Mandatory Bank Recapitalization
summary: European policy makers shouldn't force obligatory, indiscriminate recapitalization on the continent's banks without first resolving public debt problems, Banco Santander SA's chairman said.

headline: E.U. Sees Solution to India Telecom Security Spat
summary: The European Union and India are likely to resolve a dispute over new Indian telecommunications security rules that European equipment suppliers fear will limit their access to the country's fast-growing market, E.U. trade chief Karel De Gucht said.

headline: Chevron Drilling Off South China Coast by Year-End
summary: Chevron plans to start drilling its first gas exploration well off the southern coast of China before the end of the year, near an area where large gas reserves have been found.

headline: HDFC Plans To Raise $40.5 Million Via Bonds
summary: India's Housing Development Finance plans to raise $40.5 million via two-year, zero-coupon bonds, three people familiar with the development said.

headline: Ex-Fed Governor Expects Inflation Objective
summary: The U.S. Federal Reserve's next move could be to introduce an explicit inflation objective, to give it room to provide additional stimulus while keeping long-term inflation expectations under control, former Fed Gov. Laurence Meyer said.

headline: India Shares End Down 1.6%
summary: Indian shares closed lower for a second straight session Tuesday, led by Tata Consultancy Services after the software exporter's below-forecast July-September earnings and cautious outlook disappointed investors.

headline: Singh Sees India, Brazil, South Africa Coordination at G-20
summary: Brazil, India and South Africa should negotiate as a block at the Group of 20 meeting of leading nations in Paris next month, Indian Prime Minister Manmohan Singh said.

headline: India's Gold, Silver Inventories Pile Up
summary: Gold and silver sales are sluggish nearly three weeks into India's peak festival season but will likely pick up Thursday because of an auspicious occasion, traders said.

headline: Tata Motors Considering Factories in Latin America, Southeast Asia
summary: Tata Motors is considering building factories to make trucks and buses in Latin America and Southeast Asia, a senior executive at India's largest auto maker by revenue said.

headline: India Gives Conditional Ok to Coal India for Investment Overseas
summary: India's federal government has given conditional approval to Coal India's long-awaited proposal to buy unlisted units of listed mining companies overseas, a senior coal ministry official and a senior company official said.

headline: Labor Behind Diwali
summary: As the Hindu festival of lights Diwali draws near, laborers throughout the country are hard at work preparing traditional items for the festival, from earthen lamps to idols of goddesses. Some snapshots.

headline: Patni Computer Profit Drops 41%
summary: Patni Computer Systems reported a 41% fall in consolidated net profit for the third quarter, weighed by higher expenses and foreign-exchange losses.

headline: BP's Limited Legal Relief
summary: BP is gradually coming to terms with other companies involved in the Macondo oil spill. Dealing with the disaster's full legacy is still another matter.

headline: HCL Technologies Profit Jumps 50%
summary: HCL Technologies topped market forecast for net profit, but its revenue missed estimates, deepening concerns about the Indian software sector's outlook as the results came a day after market leader Tata Consultancy Services Ltd.'s disappointing performance.

headline: India to Grant Internet Service License to Qualcomm Unit
summary: India's telecommunications department has decided to grant a unit of Qualcomm a license to offer Internet services, Telecom Secretary R. Chandrashekhar said.

headline: Telstra Investors Approve Internet Deal
summary: Telstra Corp. shareholders voted for the company to participate in the federal government's plan to roll out high speed Internet around the country, in a deal worth $11.2 billion.

headline: TomTom Takes Full Ownership of Indian Operations
summary: Dutch navigation equipment maker TomTom said it has taken full ownership of its fast-growing Indian operations, raising its stake in the joint venture from 90% previously.

headline: Infosys Expects Strong Sales Growth in Europe
summary: Infosys is hoping to turn the tide in Europe, where the technology company's revenue has remained stagnant for the past three years.

headline: Australia: China Hard Landing Unlikely
summary: Australia's surging terms of trade will remain robust in the coming years as China is unlikely to have a hard landing from its soaring economic growth, Australia's Treasury Secretary said.

headline: Former UBNZ Executive Charged With Bribery
summary: Hong Kong's anti-graft agency said it charged May Hao, a former executive of UBNZ Asset Holdings, with offering bribes to seal a recent takeover.

headline: India's Hunger Woes
summary: Despite the country's rapid economic growth, many in India still suffer from hunger and malnutrition. In pictures.

headline: HTC Takes a Blow in Apple Fight
summary: The International Trade Commission ruled Apple didn't violate HTC's patents for technology used in its mobile devices, a setback for the Taiwanese company in the global battle over the smartphone market.

headline: India in Pictures
summary: India seals another big win over England in One Day International cricket, a boy paints earthen lamps for Diwali, Muslims depart for Hajj pilgrimage from Srinagar, and more.

headline: Qantas to Ground More Aircraft
summary: In response to concerted strikes by staff, Australia's Qantas Airways said it will ground more aircraft. The move will cut domestic capacity by as much as 20,000 seats.

headline: ONGC Share Sale Likely by December
summary: Oil & Natural Gas Corp.'s follow-on share sale will likely happen by December, India's finance ministry said.

headline: Deals India: Morning News Roundup
summary: News roundup from Indian newspapers, news wires and Web sites on Tuesday, October 18, 2011. Deals India has not verified the stories from other media organizations and does not vouch for their accuracy.

headline: Sabic's Net Profit Jumps 54%
summary: Saudi Basic Industries Corp., or Sabic, said its third-quarter net profit surged 54%, beating expectations, as output and sales volumes increased and product prices improved.

headline: Newborns Need to Be Near Their Mothers at Night
summary: Significant physiological stress and disrupted sleep patterns were recorded in 2-day-old newborns who were physically separated from their mothers but remained within close proximity in the same room, according to a study in Biological Psychiatry.

headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications for the edition of Oct. 18, 2011

headline: Living Lab Sets Up at a Seniors Residence
summary: Scientists are getting some real-life lessons on how to stave off the effects of old age.

headline: Dutrow Granted 30-Day Stay
summary: Former Kentucky Derby-winning horse trainer Richard Dutrow Jr. can continue working in New York State for 30 days due to a stay granted by New York State Supreme Court in Schenectady on Monday.

headline: High Line Taps New Art Chief
summary: Cecilia Alemani, appointed to expand the High Line's art program, envisions a 19-block-long sculpture garden and dance performances on the walkways.

headline: Motel Latest Stopover in Forfeiture Battle
summary: The $57-a-night Motel Caswell, magnet for hard-luck cases, police patrol cars and the occasional drug deal, is the unlikely prize in a high-stakes tug-of-war between conservative legal activists and the government.

headline: Einhorn Blasts Green Mountain Coffee
summary: Hedge-fund manager David Einhorn devoted an entire hour-long presentation to knocking around Green Mountain Coffee Roasters, one of this year's best-performing U.S. stocks.

headline: El Paso CEO Set for $91 Million in Exit Pay
summary: El Paso CEO Douglas Foshee is in line for exit pay of $91 million following El Paso's sale to Kinder Morgan. It would be one of the largest ever packages for a CEO following a merger.

headline: Fashion Week's Instigator
summary: The Wall Street Journal interviews Fern Mallis, who spearhead the creation of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Branson's Galactic Bash
summary: With flair, British billionaire Sir Richard Branson christened Spaceport America in a remote New Mexico desert Monday. The facility will serve as the base for his Virgin Galactic space-tourism business.

headline: Portugal Unveils Deep Cuts
summary: Portugal's government unveiled harsh new austerity measures to control its budget deficit over the next two years, as it seeks to convince European peers that it has the political will to keep the promises it made when it was bailed out.

headline: Courtroom Showdown
summary: "Gunfight" tells the story of how the Supreme Court finally came to rule on the meaning of the right 'to keep and bear arms.' Jonathan Karl reviews.

headline: Court to Rule If Abuses Abroad Can Lead to Suits
summary: The Supreme Court said it will consider a lawsuit against Royal Dutch Shell to decide whether corporations can be sued in U.S. courts for allegedly aiding human-rights abuses overseas.

headline: Living by Reactors, Japanese Are Split
summary: A growing divide among Japanese communities near reactors illustrates the collapse of a 40-year national consensus promoting nuclear power.

headline: SUNY Board Gets Overhaul
summary: Gov. Andrew Cuomo shook up the leadership of the State University of New York, replacing its board chairman with H. Carl McCall, a former state comptroller and a longtime prominent African-American figure in Democratic local politics.

headline: IPhone 4S Answers Sports Questions
summary: Using the new iPhone 4S, we asked Siri some sports questions. Siri's answers (which are all real) seemed pretty…Siri-ous.

headline: Risks Haunted Fatal Car Race
summary: Sunday's IndyCar Series race was supposed to be a showcase event for a struggling sport undergoing a transformation. Essential to attracting new crowds was increasing the risks on the racetrack.

headline: Floodwaters Hammer Thailand
summary: Damages from Thailand's worst flooding in decades continued to mount as parts of another industrial estate were inundated and residents worried that Bangkok remained vulnerable despite recent receding waters.

headline: Traders Warn of Market Cracks
summary: Amid the wild swings of the past few weeks, cracks are appearing deep in the workings of the stock market that some professional investors say are making the market treacherous to trade.

headline: Panel Faults Virus Test to Spot Cervical Cancer
summary: An influential federal health-care task force is expected to oppose testing for the human papillomavirus to detect cervical cancer in women over age 30.

headline: Democrats Seek Funds for States
summary: Senate Democrats plan to bring a bill forward that would send $35 billion to state and local governments to allow them to rehire unemployed public-sector workers—the first measure from Obama's job plan that Democrats will try to move forward as a standalone bill.

headline: What's News
summary: Here are the top business stories from today's Wall Street Journal Asia.

headline: Spain Bests Italy in Bond Market
summary: But betting on Spain isn't without risks, including the possibility that its high private-sector debt will weigh on the sovereign sufficiently to see it downgraded.

headline: Trumpets Taking the City
summary: Trumpets will be center stage during the two most attention-worthy events this week: the ninth annual Festival of New Trumpet Music, and Tom Harrell's week-long run at the Village Vanguard.

headline: Afghan Probe Sheds Light on Killing
summary: A four-minute peace offering recorded onto a cellphone won the trust of Afghan President Hamid Karzai and his top advisers—and clinched a plot that led to the killing of their chief peace negotiator.

headline: Richard Holledge: Britain's All-Seeing Private Eye
summary: The magazine that joyously exposes the 'smugness and hypocrisy' of the high and mighty.

headline: Wells Fargo Profit Rises, Revenue Slips
summary: Wells Fargo's third-quarter profit rose 21% as expenses fell, but revenue declined and fell short of Wall Street analysts' expectations.

headline: Dana Rohrabacher: A Balkan Peace Bargain
summary: Transferring territory and population between Serbia and Kosovo could bolster long-term stability.

headline: Japan Plant's Radioactive Leaks Diminish
summary: The operator of the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant said emissions of radioactive materials from the quake-hit plant have fallen by half over the past month, a major step forward in efforts to stabilize the facility.

headline: New York City's Cheapest Homes
summary: A Wall Street Journal analysis of borough-by-borough data compiled by PropertyShark.com reveals a diverse mix of properties at the extreme low end of the market.

headline: Index Changes Weigh on Oil
summary: West Texas Intermediate, once the unassailable global crude-oil benchmark, is under siege on a new front. Managers of key commodities indexes plan to decrease the weighting of WTI and increase the weighting of its rival, European Brent blend.

headline: Apple's Core Question: Whither Its Cash?
summary: Shareholders will want to know what new CEO Tim Cook plans to do about the tech company's cash hoard, $82 billion by one estimate.

headline: Painting the Town Pink to Raise Millions
summary: The ninth annual Avon Walk for Breast Cancer, which took place this weekend in New York, was big business.

headline: Dear White House: Tell the Truth About E.T.
summary: When the White House promised to answer citizen petitions on the most pressing problems of the day, it may not have had extraterrestrial life in mind.

headline: Lowe's Cuts Back on Stores
summary: Lowe's said it will close 20 under-performing stores in 15 states within a month. The home-improvement retailer also plans to open only 10 to 15 stores a year in North America beginning next year, instead of 30 annually.

headline: Eastern Europe Faces Bleak Outlook
summary: Economies in Central and Eastern Europe with close trade and financial links to the euro zone will slow sharply next year as a result of the currency area's sovereign-debt crisis, the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development said.

headline: Wall Street Protests Test Police Playbook
summary: The Occupy Wall Street demonstrations have posed a test for the New York Police blueprint for handling large crowds developed over the past 20 years.

headline: Mislabeling China Risk at Wal-Mart
summary: For foreign food retailers, a slice of China's market looks appetizing. But as Wal-Mart Stores is finding out in the furor over mislabeled pork, food safety and political risks can make it hard to digest.

section: New York House of the Day
headline: Low-End Digs
summary: The Wall Street Journal set out to find the least expensive homes for sale in New York City. Here's a sampling of what awaits buyers at the bottom of the market.

headline: The NFC East Lacks a Clear Pecking Order
summary: The Giants beat the Eagles by 13. The Eagles beat the Redskins by a touchdown. The Redskins beat the Giants by two touchdowns. And the 2-3 Cowboys are the only team that's perfect in the division. Where's the patsy? Where's the—ahem, Vince Young—Dream Team?

headline: Amerigas to Buy Energy Transfer's Propane Operations
summary: Energy Transfer Partners is selling its propane operations for $2.8 billion to AmeriGas Partners in order to focus on its natural-gas pipeline business.

headline: Oceanfront in Carmel
summary: This 4,533-square-foot house in Carmel, Calif., sits on more than an acre and offers views of the Pacific, where otters, dolphins and whales pass by, the owner says.

headline: Halliburton Rides Drilling Rebound
summary: Halliburton's third-quarter net profit rose 26% as a North American drilling rebound showed no signs of slowing, despite uncertainty about the global economy.

headline: Van Buren and Obama on the Banks
summary: Your editorial "The Banker Baiters" (Oct. 6) quotes President Obama as saying "[banks] don't have some inherent right to, you know, get a certain amount of profit." Democratic presidents all the way back to Martin Van Buren have been taunting the banks and blaming them for recessions.

headline: Research of Mice and Men
summary: Nathan LeBrasseur's work is an unusual combination of mouse research and human research.

headline: David Skeel: The Euro Crisis—Lessons From Bear Stearns
summary: Europe can't afford to bail out Italy, so it might as well send the right message now by forcing Greece to restructure its debt.

headline: Kinder Morgan's Exxon Moment
summary: The oft-overlooked pipelines sector is having its super-major moment. Kinder Morgan's proposed takeover of El Paso, worth $38 billion including assumed debt, is of oil major proportions.

headline: Officer Charged With False Arrest
summary: A New York City police officer already under investigation for an attempted insurance fraud involving his snow-removal business was charged with falsely arresting and violating the civil rights of an African-American man.

headline: Philips Cuts 4,500 Jobs
summary: Electronics company Philips said its net profit fell sharply in the third quarter owing to weak consumer demand, and announced 4,500 job cuts as part of a cost-cutting program.

headline: Bad Marks for College-Savings Plans May Not Call for a Time Out
summary: Third-quarter report cards are in for college-savings plans and the results are likely to trouble many parents.

headline: This App Is for the Birds
summary: Ralph Gardner Jr. goes searching for the ultimate bird app, settling on the iBird Explorer Pro 4.0.

headline: ObamaCare Starts to Unravel
summary: The real story behind the Class program failure, and what to do now.

headline: Hard Times for the Motel Caswell
summary: The $57-a-night Motel Caswell is the unlikely prize in a high-stakes tug-of-war between conservative legal activists and the government.

headline: Yuja Wang: The Fast and the Serious
summary: Her handlers have tried to show that she's a serious young artist with more to her formidable talent than jaw-dropping technique. But the spirited 24-year-old's antics keep getting in the way.

headline: IBM's Worries Persist
summary: IBM's quarterly profit and sales rose amid growth in emerging markets, but the technology giant failed to dispel investors' concerns about the health of technology spending.

headline: The Wal-Mart Ripple Effect
summary: Federal courts curb frivolous class-action suits against lenders.
